title: Red-Eyed Tree Frog Feeding Guide
description: Comprehensive feeding guide for Red-Eyed Tree Frogs covering insect selection, gut-loading, supplementation, feeding schedules, and troubleshooting picky eaters.
excerpt: Comprehensive feeding guide for Red-Eyed Tree Frogs covering insect selection, gut-loading, supplementation, feeding schedules, and troubleshooting picky eaters.

content.heading: Understanding Red-Eyed Tree Frog Nutrition
content.text: Red-Eyed Tree Frogs (Agalychnis callidryas) are obligate insectivores - their entire diet consists of live (or convincingly presented dead) insects. In the wild, they're opportunistic hunters that consume whatever appropriately-sized prey wanders onto their perch during nighttime foraging: moths, flies, crickets, small beetles, and other soft-bodied invertebrates. Captive nutrition requires replicating this variety while addressing the nutritional deficiencies inherent in commercially-raised feeder insects. Unlike wild insects that feed on diverse plants and accumulate minerals from natural sources, captive-bred feeders are nutritionally incomplete - they lack calcium, essential vitamins, and proper calcium:phosphorus ratios. Without gut-loading (enriching feeders before offering) and dusting (coating with supplements), captive frogs develop metabolic bone disease, vitamin deficiencies, and shortened lifespans.
Red-Eyed Tree Frogs accept a wide variety of insects, but show individual preferences and pickiness:

rows: Most accepted feeder. Remove hind legs if frogs struggle to catch.
Excellent nutrition, less smell than crickets. Some frogs ignore them initially.
High calcium, no gut-loading needed. Very nutritious.
High fat - obesity risk if overfed. Use sparingly.
High moisture, good for hydration. Low calcium.
Too small for adult frogs except as variety.
Excellent nutrition but expensive and hard to source.
Hard exoskeleton, less digestible. Many frogs refuse.
High fat, aggressive mandibles. Not ideal.
Pesticide/parasite risk. Never feed wild-caught prey.

content.text: Rule of thumb for sizing: Prey width should be NO LARGER than the distance between frog's eyes. Slightly smaller is safer than slightly larger.
NEVER feed wild-caught insects (moths, flies, grasshoppers from outside). Risk of pesticide poisoning, parasites, and bacterial contamination.
Red-Eyed Tree Frogs have a reputation for being picky, unpredictable eaters:

items: Individual Variation: Some frogs eagerly eat anything offered. Others refuse entire insect types for no apparent reason.
Inconsistent Preferences: A frog may love crickets for months, then suddenly ignore them and only accept roaches.
Worm Aversion: Many (but not all) Red-Eyed Tree Frogs refuse mealworms, superworms, and other elongated prey. Likely due to unfamiliar movement patterns.
Neophobia: Frogs raised on one feeder type may refuse new insects initially. Requires gradual introduction.
Mood-Based: Even well-fed frogs sometimes ignore food for 1-2 weeks with no health issues, then resume eating normally.
Movement Dependency: Prey MUST move to trigger feeding response. Motionless insects are invisible to frogs.

content.text: Strategies for Picky Eaters:

items: Offer variety - rotate 3-4 insect types weekly rather than one staple
Feed during peak activity hours (7-9pm) when frogs are naturally hunting
Use feeding tongs to animate dead/sluggish insects
Start new feeders when frog is very hungry (skip one feeding first)
Remove crickets after 2 hours - they bite sleeping frogs and cause stress
Try canned/vacuum-packed insects for stubborn individuals (pre-supplemented)

content.text: Gut-loading is feeding your feeders nutritious food 24-48 hours before offering to frogs. This transfers nutrition from feeder's gut into your frog:
Commercial Gut-Load Diets (Best):

items: Repashy Superload or Bug Burger - complete balanced formula
Cricket Crack or Fluker's High Calcium Cricket Diet
Contains optimal calcium:phosphorus ratios, vitamins, minerals
Just add water to powder, offer to feeders 24-48hr before feeding out

content.text: DIY Gut-Load Formula (Budget Option):

items: Base: High-quality fish flakes or whole grain cereal (calcium-fortified)
Calcium Source: Crushed cuttlebone or calcium powder mixed in
Vegetables: Thinly sliced sweet potato, carrots, leafy greens (kale, collards)
Fruit: Small amounts of apple, orange, or bee pollen for vitamins
Moisture: Water crystals or fresh vegetables for hydration
Avoid: Iceberg lettuce (no nutrition), spinach (calcium binding), dog/cat food (inappropriate protein)

rows: Commercial diet, sweet potato, carrots, bee pollen
Commercial diet, leafy greens, apple slices
Commercial diet, carrots, oats, calcium powder
Contain little gut content, primarily fat stores
Hornworm chow or mulberry leaves only (won't eat alternatives)

content.text: Gut-loading is NOT optional - it's the PRIMARY way frogs receive vitamins and minerals. Supplements are secondary backup, not replacement.
Even with perfect gut-loading, feeder insects lack sufficient calcium and vitamin D3. Dusting (coating insects with powder) fills these gaps:
Standard Supplementation Schedule:

rows: Every 3rd feeding add extra calcium (no D3)

content.text: Recommended Products:

items: Exo Terra Calcium + D3 - provides calcium carbonate + cholecalciferol (D3)
Exo Terra Multi Vitamin - broad spectrum vitamins A, B, C, E, amino acids
Mix Protocol: Combine equal parts Calcium+D3 and Multivitamin in small container, shake before each use

content.text: 'Shake and Bake' Dusting Method:

items: Place appropriate number of feeder insects in plastic cup or bag
Add 1/4 teaspoon supplement powder mix
Gently shake/tumble until insects evenly coated (looks like powdered donuts)
Immediately offer to frogs - dust falls off within 10-20 minutes
For canned insects, dust them after removing from can/pouch

content.text: Never skip dusting. Underage supplementation causes metabolic bone disease within 6-12 months. This is the #1 cause of preventable death in captive amphibians.

rows: Mature metabolism, risk of obesity if overfed
Replenish depleted reserves after egg laying

content.text: How Much to Feed:

items: Offer insects until frog loses interest (usually 5-10 minutes)
Remove uneaten feeders after 2 hours (crickets bite sleeping frogs)
Frog should have slightly rounded belly after feeding, not distended/bulging
If frog refuses food 2+ feedings in a row BUT is alert and active, skip one feeding and try again
Weight loss, lethargy, or sunken appearance = urgent vet visit

content.text: Free-Range Feeding (Standard Method):

items: Release dusted insects into enclosure during evening hours (7-9pm)
Insects climb on plants/branches where frogs encounter them
Most natural method - stimulates hunting behavior
Pros: Natural, low stress, encourages exercise
Cons: Difficult to count exact intake, crickets may hide and bite frogs later, can't monitor individual frog intake in groups

content.text: Tong Feeding (Recommended for Picky Eaters):

items: Use feeding tongs (8-10" length) to hold insect
Wiggle insect slowly in front of frog's face to simulate movement
Frog strikes, loosen grip so it can grab prey
Pros: Ensures each frog eats, can train frogs to accept canned insects, controlled portions
Cons: Time-consuming, must be patient, some frogs scared by tongs initially
Training Period: 1-3 weeks before most frogs accept tong feeding

content.text: Feeding Dish (Not Recommended for Tree Frogs):

items: Placing insects in dish works for terrestrial frogs, not arboreal species
Red-Eyed Tree Frogs rarely descend to ground level to feed
Only viable if using climbing insects (roaches) and dish is elevated

content.text: Exo Terra offers 11 varieties of pre-cooked, supplemented insects that can be valuable for picky eaters or backup food:
Benefits:

items: Already gut-loaded and vitamin-calcium coated - no prep needed
Softened exoskeleton (easier digestion than live)
Shelf-stable for years - excellent emergency backup
No escapees, no cricket noise, no feeder maintenance
Contains collagen from retorting process - aids bone/cartilage growth

content.text: How to Use:

items: Open can/pouch, drain excess liquid
Use feeding tongs to grasp single insect
Wiggle slowly in front of frog - must mimic live movement
Release tongs when frog strikes
Requires training period - most frogs need 2-4 sessions to accept
Not 100% replacement for live food, but can be 30-50% of diet

content.text: Canned insects are EXCELLENT for travel, emergencies, or when feeder supplier is out of stock. Keep 2-3 cans as backup.
Keeping feeders alive and healthy until use:
Dead/dying feeders accumulate ammonia and bacteria. Remove dead insects daily from feeder bins to prevent die-offs.
While Red-Eyed Tree Frogs get most hydration through skin absorption (see hydration guide), food insects contribute moisture:

items: High-Moisture Feeders: Hornworms (85% water), silkworms, freshly-molted insects provide bonus hydration
Standard Feeders: Gut-loaded crickets/roaches are ~70% water after eating vegetables
Low-Moisture Feeders: Mealworms, superworms are drier - offer vegetables to feeders first
Hydration Boost: If frog appears dehydrated, offer hornworms or heavily gut-loaded crickets plus increase misting

content.text: Adjust feeding for breeding groups to support egg production and male vigor:
Pre-Breeding Conditioning (4-6 weeks before rainy season trigger):

items: Increase feeding frequency - every other day instead of every 2-3 days
Boost calcium supplementation - dust every feeding with extra calcium
Offer variety - rotate 4-5 different feeder types weekly
Higher fat content acceptable - waxworms 2x weekly instead of 1x
Goal: Build fat reserves and calcium stores for egg production

content.text: During Breeding Season:

items: Maintain high feeding frequency but don't overfeed (obesity interferes with amplexus)
Extra calcium critical - females producing 40-60 eggs per clutch, multiple clutches
Feed males normally - they often eat less while calling/pursuing females
Remove uneaten feeders promptly - breeding pairs ignore food during amplexus

content.text: Post-Breeding Recovery (Females):

items: Feed heavily for 2-3 weeks - every 1-2 days with large portions
Maximum calcium supplementation - pure calcium (no D3) every 3rd feeding in addition to standard mix
High-protein feeders - crickets, roaches, silkworms preferred over waxworms
Goal: Replenish depleted calcium reserves before next breeding cycle

rows: Check temps (75-85°F), reduce stress, observe for 1 week, vet if continues
Offer new feeders when very hungry, tong-train with familiar food first, mix new/old insects
Insect too large, bad taste, calcium dust too thick
Offer smaller prey, lighter dusting, remove any dead/spoiled feeders
Fecal exam by vet, verify supplement schedule, increase feeding frequency
Overfeeding, too many waxworms, insufficient exercise
Reduce to every 3-4 days, eliminate high-fat feeders, add climbing enrichment
Vision problems, MBD (weak jaw), improper lighting
Tong-feed directly, check for MBD signs, verify UVB if used, slow-moving prey
Overfed, temps too cool, prey too large, stress
Smaller portions, verify 75-85°F basking available, reduce handling around feeding time
Feed near foliage/perches, use tongs, never rely on floor-level feeding
Remove all feeders after 2 hours, never feed crickets before daytime rest period

content.text: Well-fed Red-Eyed Tree Frogs display these indicators:

items: Body Condition: Rounded (not bulging) belly, visible muscle tone in limbs, no visible hip bones
Activity Level: Alert and responsive during evening hours, actively hunts offered prey
Growth Rate: Juveniles double size every 2-3 months with proper feeding
Coloration: Vibrant green dorsal color, bright red eyes, no dull/dark stress coloration
Breeding Success: Females produce multiple clutches per season, high egg viability
Longevity: Reach 5-8+ year lifespan with proper nutrition (vs 2-3 years with deficiencies)
No MBD Signs: Strong grip strength, straight spine, no tremors or difficulty climbing

content.text: Approximate monthly feeding costs (one adult frog):

rows: Crickets, roaches, waxworms + supplements + commercial gut-load
5+ feeder types, canned backup, premium supplements, breeding colony maintenance
Scale above costs by frog quantity plus extra calcium for breeding females

content.text: Raising your own Dubia roach colony can reduce long-term costs by 50-70% after initial setup investment of $50-100.
Always have backup food sources in case your supplier runs out or you can't restock:

items: Keep 2-3 cans of Exo Terra canned crickets or grasshoppers (shelf-stable for years)
Maintain small Dubia roach breeding colony as self-sustaining backup
Know 2-3 local pet stores that carry feeders as alternatives to online orders
Red-Eyed Tree Frogs can safely fast 1-2 weeks if healthy - don't panic if you miss a feeding
Never resort to wild-caught insects as emergency food - poisoning risk too high
